title.value: Commonality in Recommender Systems: Evaluating Recommender Systems to Enhance Cultural Citizenship
title.justification: This is the title of the provided research paper
title.quote:
Commonality in Recommender Systems: Evaluating
Recommender Systems to Enhance Cultural Citizenship

extractions.description: This paper introduces the concept of commonality as a measure for recommender systems in cultural contexts, emphasizing shared cultural experience and diversity. The authors propose this metric to complement existing utility, diversity, and fairness metrics, arguing it better aligns with public service goals like cultural citizenship. The paper includes theoretical foundations, interdisciplinary dialogue, and empirical analysis using movies, music, and literature datasets.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical analysis using datasets from movies, music, and literature to evaluate the proposed metric.
type.quote:
We empirically compare the performance of recommendation algorithms using commonality with existing utility, diversity, novelty, and fairness metrics using
three different domains.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on evaluating and proposing measures for recommender systems.
name.quote:
Commonality in Recommender Systems: Evaluating
Recommender Systems to Enhance Cultural Citizenship

name.value: Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency in Machine Learning
name.justification: The paper discusses fairness in recommender systems and the broader social impact of these systems on cultural content distribution.
name.quote:
Concerns about personalization often center on filter bubbles that keep individuals in taste echo chambers...we are concerned not only with the social effects of individualization but with the need for greater diversity in the curation and distribution of cultural content and the benefits of promoting a shared
diversity of cultural experience.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the recommendation of cultural content like music, movies, and literature.
name.quote: Recommender systems have become the dominant means of curating cultural content, significantly influencing the nature of individual cultural experience.

name.justification: The paper includes BPRMF as one of the models in the empirical evaluation.
name.quote: We use models based on MF2020, NeuMF, RP3beta, BPRMF and iALS trained of both binarized and original input.

is_contributed.justification: BPRMF is not contributed by this paper but is used for comparison in the empirical study,
is_contributed.quote: We use models based on MF2020, NeuMF, RP3beta, BPRMF and iALS trained of both binarized and original input.

is_executed.justification: The model is evaluated empirically in the study.
is_executed.quote: We trained 12 recommender systems for the last.fm data using the Elliot library. We use models based on MF2020, NeuMF, RP3beta, BPRMF and iALS trained of both binarized and original input.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared to others using the proposed commonality metric and traditional utility, diversity, and fairness metrics.
is_compared.quote: Our results demonstrate that existing high-utility recommendation algorithms under-perform in terms of commonality...

referenced_paper_title.value: BPR: Bayesian Personalized Ranking from Implicit Feedback
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper for the BPRMF model.

name.justification: This dataset was used in the empirical evaluation for the movies domain.
name.quote: We use the movielens-1m dataset, which contains 1,000,209 ratings of approximately 3,900 movies from 6,040 users from the movielens platform.

referenced_paper_title.value: Collaborative Filtering for Implicit Feedback Datasets
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the movielens-1m dataset is on collaborative filtering for implicit feedback datasets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For this dataset, we used rankings from multiple recommendation systems prepared by Valcarce et al.

name.justification: This dataset was used in the empirical evaluation for the music domain.
name.quote: For music, we use Last.fm-2b dataset, which is the largest dataset containing usersâ€™ listening events for 120,000 Last.fm users, and over two billion listening events.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the Last.fm-2b dataset is on the Million Song Dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For music, we use Last.fm-2b dataset...We trained 12 recommender systems for the last.fm data using the Elliot library.

name.justification: This dataset was used in the empirical evaluation for the literature domain.
name.quote: For literature, we use the Librarything dataset, containing user book ratings.

referenced_paper_title.value: Enhancing the Performance of Recommender Systems with User-Centric Similarity Measures
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the Librarything dataset is on user-centric similarity measures in recommender systems.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For this dataset, we also used rankings from multiple recommendation systems prepared by Valcarce et al.

name.justification: The Elliot library was used for training and evaluating the recommender models in the empirical study.
name.quote: We trained 12 recommender systems for the last.fm data using the Elliot library.

referenced_paper_title.value: Elliot: a Comprehensive and Rigorous Framework for Evaluating Recommender Systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides a comprehensive framework for evaluating recommender systems.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We trained 12 recommender systems for the last.fm data using the Elliot library.
